Name: Actinium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'actinos', meaning a ray

Name: Aluminum
NameOrigin: the Latin name for alum, 'alumen' meaning bitter salt

Name: Americium
NameOrigin: Americas, the continent where the element was first synthesized

Name: Antimony
NameOrigin: the Greek 'anti – monos', meaning not alone (stibium in Latin)

Name: Argon
NameOrigin: the Greek, 'argos', meaning idle

Name: Arsenic
NameOrigin: the Greek name 'arsenikon' for the yellow pigment orpiment

Name: Astatine
NameOrigin: the Greek 'astatos', meaning unstable

Name: Gold
NameOrigin: the Anglo-Saxon word gold (aurum in Latin, meaning glow of sunrise)[2]

Name: Boron
NameOrigin: the Arabic 'buraq', which was the name for borax

Name: Barium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'barys', meaning heavy

Name: Beryllium
NameOrigin: the Greek name for beryl, 'beryllo'

Name: Bohrium
NameOrigin: Niels Bohr, physicist

Name: Bismuth
NameOrigin: the German 'Bisemutum' a corruption of 'Weisse Masse' meaning white mass

Name: Berkelium
NameOrigin: Berkeley, California, USA, where the element was first synthesized

Name: Bromine
NameOrigin: the Greek 'bromos' meaning stench

Name: Carbon
NameOrigin: the Latin 'carbo', meaning charcoal

Name: Calcium
NameOrigin: the Latin 'calx' meaning lime

Name: Cadmium
NameOrigin: the Latin name for the mineral calmine, 'cadmia'

Name: Cerium
NameOrigin: Ceres, the Roman God of agriculture

Name: Californium
NameOrigin: State of California, USA, where the element was first synthesized

Name: Chlorine
NameOrigin: the Greek 'chloros', meaning greenish yellow

Name: Curium
NameOrigin: Pierre Curie, a physicist, and Marie Curie, a physicist and chemist

Name: Cobalt
NameOrigin: the German word 'kobald', meaning goblin

Name: Chromium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'chroma', meaning colour

Name: Cesium
NameOrigin: the Latin 'caesius', meaning sky blue

Name: Copper
NameOrigin: the Old English name coper in turn derived from the Latin 'Cyprium aes', meaning a metal from Cyprus

Name: Dubnium
NameOrigin: Dubna, Russia

Name: Dysprosium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'dysprositos', meaning hard to get

Name: Erbium
NameOrigin: Ytterby, Sweden

Name: Einsteinium
NameOrigin: Albert Einstein, physicist

Name: Europium
NameOrigin: Europe

Name: Fluorine
NameOrigin: the Latin 'fluere', meaning to flow

Name: Iron
NameOrigin: the Anglo-Saxon name iren (ferrum in Latin)

Name: Fermium
NameOrigin: Enrico Fermi, physicist

Name: Francium
NameOrigin: France, where it was first discovered

Name: Gallium
NameOrigin: France (with the Latin name Gallia)

Name: Gadolinium
NameOrigin: Johan Gadolin, chemist, physicist and mineralogist

Name: Germanium
NameOrigin: Germany (with the Latin name Germania)

Name: Hydrogen
NameOrigin: the Greek 'hydro' and 'genes' meaning water-forming

Name: Helium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'helios' meaning sun

Name: Hafnium
NameOrigin: Copenhagen, Denmark (with the Latin name Hafnia)

Name: Mercury
NameOrigin: Mercury, the first planet in the Solar System (Hg from former name hydrargyrum, from Greek hydr- water and argyros silver)

Name: Holmium
NameOrigin: Stockholm, Sweden (with the Latin name Holmia)

Name: Hassium
NameOrigin: Hesse, Germany, where the element was first synthesized

Name: Iodine
NameOrigin: the Greek 'iodes' meaning violet

Name: Indium
NameOrigin: the Latin 'indicium', meaning violet or indigo

Name: Iridium
NameOrigin: Iris, the Greek goddess of the rainbow

Name: Potassium
NameOrigin: the English word potash (kalium in Latin)[2]

Name: Krypton
NameOrigin: the Greek 'kryptos', meaning hidden

Name: Lanthanum
NameOrigin: the Greek 'lanthanein', meaning to lie hidden

Name: Lithium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'lithos' meaning stone

Name: Lawrencium
NameOrigin: Ernest O. Lawrence, physicist

Name: Lutetium
NameOrigin: Paris, France (with the Roman name Lutetia)

Name: Mendelevium
NameOrigin: Dmitri Mendeleyev, chemist and inventor

Name: Magnesium
NameOrigin: Magnesia, a district of Eastern Thessaly in Greece

Name: Manganese
NameOrigin: Either the Latin 'magnes', meaning magnet or from the black magnesium oxide, 'magnesia nigra'

Name: Molybdenum
NameOrigin: the Greek 'molybdos' meaning lead

Name: Meitnerium
NameOrigin: Lise Meitner, physicist

Name: Nitrogen
NameOrigin: the Greek 'nitron' and 'genes' meaning nitre-forming

Name: Sodium
NameOrigin: the English word soda (natrium in Latin)[2]

Name: Niobium
NameOrigin: Niobe, daughter of king Tantalus from Greek mythology

Name: Neodymium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'neos didymos' meaning new twin

Name: Neon
NameOrigin: the Greek 'neos', meaning new

Name: Nickel
NameOrigin: the shortened of the German 'kupfernickel' meaning either devil's copper or St. Nicholas's copper

Name: Nobelium
NameOrigin: Alfred Nobel, chemist, engineer, innovator, and armaments manufacturer

Name: Neptunium
NameOrigin: Neptune, the eighth planet in the Solar System

Name: Oxygen
NameOrigin: the Greek 'oxy' and 'genes' meaning acid-forming

Name: Osmium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'osme', meaning smell

Name: Phosphorus
NameOrigin: the Greek 'phosphoros', meaning bringer of light

Name: Protactinium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'protos', meaning first, as a prefix to the element actinium, which is produced through the radioactive decay of protactinium

Name: Lead
NameOrigin: the Anglo-Saxon lead (plumbum in Latin)[2]

Name: Palladium
NameOrigin: the then recently discovered asteroid Pallas, considered a planet at the time

Name: Promethium
NameOrigin: Prometheus of Greek mythology who stole fire from the Gods and gave it to humans

Name: Polonium
NameOrigin: Poland, the native country of Marie Curie, who first isolated the element

Name: Praseodymium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'prasinos didymos' meaning green twin

Name: Platinum
NameOrigin: the Spanish 'platina', meaning little silver

Name: Plutonium
NameOrigin: Pluto, a dwarf planet in the Solar System

Name: Radium
NameOrigin: the Latin 'radius', meaning ray

Name: Rubidium
NameOrigin: the Latin 'rubidius', meaning deepest red

Name: Rhenium
NameOrigin: Rhine, a river that flows from Grisons in the eastern Swiss Alps to the North Sea coast in the Netherlands (with the Latin name Rhenia)

Name: Rutherfordium
NameOrigin: Ernest Rutherford, chemist and physicist

Name: Rhodium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'rhodon', meaning rose coloured

Name: Radon
NameOrigin: From radium, as it was first detected as an emission from radium during radioactive decay

Name: Ruthenium
NameOrigin: Russia (with the Latin name Ruthenia)

Name: Sulfur
NameOrigin: Either from the Sanskrit 'sulvere', or the Latin 'sulfurium', both names for sulfur[2]

Name: Silver
NameOrigin: the Anglo-Saxon name siolfur (argentum in Latin)[2]

Name: Scandium
NameOrigin: Scandinavia (with the Latin name Scandia)

Name: Selenium
NameOrigin: Moon (with the Greek name selene)

Name: Seaborgium
NameOrigin: Glenn T. Seaborg, scientist

Name: Silicon
NameOrigin: the Latin 'silex' or 'silicis', meaning flint

Name: Samarium
NameOrigin: Samarskite, the name of the mineral from which it was first isolated

Name: Strontium
NameOrigin: Strontian, a small town in Scotland

Name: Tantalum
NameOrigin: King Tantalus, father of Niobe from Greek mythology

Name: Terbium
NameOrigin: Ytterby, Sweden

Name: Technetium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'tekhnetos' meaning artificial

Name: Tellurium
NameOrigin: Earth, the third planet in the solar system (with the Latin word tellus)

Name: Thorium
NameOrigin: Thor, the Scandinavian god of thunder

Name: Tin
NameOrigin: the Anglo-Saxon word tin (stannum in Latin, meaning hard)

Name: Titanium
NameOrigin: Titans, the sons of the Earth goddess of Greek mythology

Name: Thallium
NameOrigin: the Greek 'thallos', meaning a green twig

Name: Thulium
NameOrigin: Thule, the ancient name for Scandinavia

Name: Uranium
NameOrigin: Uranus, the seventh planet in the Solar System

Name: Copernicium
NameOrigin: Nicolaus Copernicus, astronomer

Name: Darmstadtium
NameOrigin: Darmstadt, Germany, where the element was first synthesized

Name: Roentgenium
NameOrigin: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, physicist

Name: Vanadium
NameOrigin: Vanadis, an old Norse name for the Scandinavian goddess Freyja

Name: Tungsten
NameOrigin: the Swedish 'tung sten' meaning heavy stone (W is wolfram, the old name of the tungsten mineral wolframite)[2]

Name: Xenon
NameOrigin: the Greek 'xenos' meaning stranger

Name: Yttrium
NameOrigin: Ytterby, Sweden

Name: Ytterbium
NameOrigin: Ytterby, Sweden

Name: Zinc
NameOrigin: the German, 'zinc', which may in turn be derived from the Persian word 'sing', meaning stone

Name: Zirconium
NameOrigin: the Persian 'zargun', meaning gold coloured
